Name: She/her used for inanimate referents
Description: She was burning good [about a house]

Name: He/him used for inanimate referents
Description: I bet thee cansnʼ climb he [= a tree]

Name: Alternative forms/phrases for referential (non-dummy) it
Description: e.g. the thing: When you on [‘switch on’] the alarm system you press this button. When you off the thing [‘switch it off’] you press that one.

Name: Alternative forms/phrases for dummy it
Description: Thass rainen ‘Itʼs raining’ (emphatic)

Name: Generalized third person singular pronoun: subject pronouns
Description: em for ‘he/she/it’

Name: Generalized third person singular pronoun: object pronouns
Description: om for ‘him/her/it’

Name: Me instead of I in coordinate subjects
Description: Me and my brother/My brother and me were late

Name: Myself/meself instead of I in coordinate subjects
Description: My/me husband and myself were late.

Name: Benefactive “personal dative” construction
Description: I got me a new car; She got her a new car; They got them a new car

Name: No gender distinction in third person singular
Description: My mother, heʼs a primary school teacher; My husband who was in England, she was by then my fiancé

Name: Regularized reflexives paradigm
Description: hisself, theirselves/theirself

Name: Object pronoun forms serving as base for first and/or second person reflexives
Description: meself for ‘myself’

Name: Subject pronoun forms serving as base for reflexives
Description: theyselves for ‘themselves’

Name: No number distinction in reflexives
Description: ourself for ‘ourselves’

Name: Absolute use of reflexives
Description: And by God, he said, … he’d be the devil if himself wouldn’t make him laugh; Himself is gone to Dublin (meaning ‘boss’, ‘head’)

Name: Emphatic reflexives with own
Description: Everybody took care of their own self.

Name: Creation of possessive pronouns with prefix fi- +personal pronoun
Description: Den no fi-me work me put yuh inna? [lit.: Then no for-me job I put you into] ‘Then wasnʼt it my job I got for you?’

Name: Subject pronoun forms as (modifying) possessive pronouns: first person singular
Description: I book for ‘my book’

Name: Subject pronoun forms as (modifying) possessive pronouns: first person plural
Description: When we done make we farm, we n’t know nothing about sell…

Name: Subject pronoun forms as (modifying) possessive pronouns: third person singular
Description: he book for ‘his book’

Name: Subject pronoun forms as (modifying) possessive pronouns: third person plural
Description: It’s they book

Name: You as (modifying) possessive pronoun
Description: Yu kyaan kom iin-ya siev yu pie yu fier ‘You canʼt come in here unless you pay your fare’

Name: Second person pronoun forms other than you as (modifying) possessive pronoun
Description: Shut unu ai, na! ‘Shut your [2PL] eyes, wonʼt you?’

Name: Object pronoun forms as (modifying) possessive pronouns: third person singular
Description: im dog ‘his dog’; get im gear on

Name: Object pronoun forms as (modifying) possessive pronouns: third person plural
Description: them book for ‘their book’

Name: Object pronoun forms as (modifying) possessive pronouns: first person singular
Description: Heʼs me brother; Iʼve lost me bike

Name: Object pronoun forms as (modifying) possessive pronouns: first person plural
Description: Us George was a nice one; We like us town;

Name: Use of us + NP in subject function
Description: Us kids used to pinch the sweets like hell.

Name: Use of us in object function with singular referent
Description: Show us [‘me’] them boots.

Name: Non-coordinated subject pronoun forms in object function
Description: e.g. You did get he out of bed in the middle of the night; Well, if I didnʼt know they, they knowed I

Name: Non-coordinated object pronoun forms in subject function
Description: Evercreech, what did ʼem [ʼtheyʼ] call it?; Us say ʼerʼs [‘she is’] dry; Usʼll do it; Huz san him? ‘Whose son is he?’

Name: Distinction between emphatic vs. non-emphatic forms of pronouns
Description: in vs. ì: ì bì in [emphatic 3SG] we ì [unstressed 3SG] mek govanment no put mo presha fo wi. [lit.: It be that what it make government not put more pressure for we] ‘That is what prevents the government from using more pressure on us.’

Name: Independent possessive pronoun forms with added nasal
Description: hern, hisn, ourn; hersn, oursn, ourns

Name: Forms or phrases for the second person plural pronoun other than you
Description: youse; yʼall; aayʼ; yufela; you…together; all of you; you ones/ʼuns; you guys; you people

Name: Forms or phrases for the second person singular pronoun other than you
Description: ye

Name: Distinct forms for inclusive/exclusive first person non-singular
Description: afla (inclusive, i.e. ‘we, including you’) vs. mifela (exclusive, i.e. ‘we, not including you’)

Name: More number distinctions in personal pronouns than simply singular vs. plural
Description: hem (3SG), tufala (3DU), trifala (3TRI), ol(geta) (3PL)

Name: Specialized plural markers for pronouns
Description: us-gang (1PL.); as gaiz (1PL), yu gaiz (2PL), dem gaiz (3PL)

Name: Plural forms of interrogative pronouns: using additional elements
Description: Who-all did you say was gonna be there?

Name: Plural forms of interrogative pronouns: reduplication
Description: Who-who came? ‘Who (of several people) came?’; What-what they said? ‘What (different) things did they say?’

Name: Singular it for plural they in anaphoric use
Description: Those books are very informative. It can be obtained at Dillon’s.

Name: Object pronoun drop
Description: mi laekem Ø ‘I like it’; A: You got tickets? – B: No, Ø sold Ø alreadyʼA: Do you have tickets? B: No, I sold them alreadyʼ

Name: Subject pronoun drop: referential pronouns
Description: A: You got tickets? – B: No, Ø sold Ø already ‘A: Do you have tickets? B: No, I sold them already’

Name: Subject pronoun drop: dummy pronouns
Description: Ø rained yesterday only (emphatic)

Name: Insertion of it where StE favours zero
Description: As I made it clear before, I am going to talk about solutions, not problems; As it is the case elsewhere in Africa, much can still be done for children

Name: Deletion of it in referential it is-constructions
Description: Is very nice food; But when I move into the flat, is OK

Name: Deletion of it in non-referential it is-constructions
Description: Here is not allowed to stop the car.

Name: Regularization of plural formation: extension of -s to StE irregular plurals
Description: childrens, oxens, sheeps

Name: Regularization of plural formation: phonological regularization
Description: wifes, knifes, lifes, leafs

Name: Plural marking via preposed elements
Description: Olketa boe bae kam long naet ‘The boys will come at night’

Name: Plural marking via postposed elements
Description: Some a di woman dem single woman; clean water-mob ‘lots of clean water’

Name: Associative plural marked by postposed and them/them all/dem
Description: I have a picture of my dad and them working their own road; Miss Waaka dem laaf afta him; I saw Saras-them’s cat by the road

Name: Associative plural marked by other elements
Description: my Daddy gang ‘my Dad and his colleagues/friends/…’

Name: Group plurals
Description: That President has two Secretary of States (rather than two Secretaries of State)

Name: Different count/mass noun distinctions resulting in use of plural for StE singular
Description: woods ‘bits of wood’; How many staffs are on medical leave?; These advices are coming because they’ve already studied all of us

Name: Absence of plural marking only after quantifiers
Description: We did all our subject-Ø in English; four pound; five year

Name: Plural marking generally optional : for nouns with human referents
Description: My sister-Ø are pretty girl-Ø.

Name: Plural marking generally optional: for nouns with non-human referents
Description: The tree-Ø  donʼt grow very tall up there.

Name: Double determiners
Description: This our common problem is very serious.

Name: Use of definite article where StE has indefinite article
Description: I had the toothache; ...when theyʼd get the cold… ʼa coldʼ

Name: Use of indefinite article where StE has definite article
Description: A sun was shining.

Name: Use of zero article where StE has definite article
Description: Did you get Ø mileage-claim for that trip?; Ø main reason for their performance…

Name: Use of zero article where StE has indefinite article
Description: Then he thought, what about getting Ø girl [to marry] from India?

Name: Use of definite article where StE favours zero
Description: He was appointed sales representative at the Nestlé, Ghana Ltd.; Do they keep the goats?; Poor people were starved with the hunger

Name: Use of indefinite article where StE favours zero
Description: about a three fields

Name: Indefinite article one/wan
Description: They seen one [‘a’] green snake tangled round a tree; Di uman sel wan mango

Name: Demonstratives for definite articles
Description: That door bin close ‘the door closed’

Name: Them instead of demonstrative those
Description: in them days, one of them things

Name: Yon/yonder indicating remoteness
Description: yon oil company; yon muckle Concorde; Wi his sair foot he would never could climb yon stairs

Name: Proximal and distal demonstratives with  ʼhereʼ and  ʼthereʼ
Description: this here book vs. them there books; Dis man (ya) lek dem trosis (de)

Name: No number distinction in demonstratives
Description: I’ve watched this children .

Name: Group genitives
Description: The man I metʼs girlfriend is a real beauty(rather than The girlfriend of the man I met is a real beauty)

Name: Existential construction to express possessive
Description: Mà mòto de. [lit.: my car exist] ‘I have a car.’

Name: Phrases with for + noun to express possession: for-phrase following possessed NP
Description: nayf for Chinyere ‘Chinyereʼs knife’; aa kau fe mais bradhas ‘that cow of my brother’; the house for me ‘my house’

Name: Phrases with for + noun to express possession: for-phrase preceding possessed NP
Description: Long time he was for my sister husband ‘A long time ago he was my sisterʼs husband’

Name: Postnominal phrases with bilong/blong/long/blo to express possession
Description: dog blong/blo maan ‘the man’s dog’

Name: Omission of genitive suffix; possession expressed through bare juxtaposition of nouns
Description: my daddy brother

Name: Double comparatives and superlatives
Description: That is so much more easier to follow.

Name: Regularized comparison strategies: extension of synthetic marking
Description: He is the regularest kind of guy I know.

Name: Regularized comparison strategies: extension of analytic marking
Description: one of the most pretty sunsets

Name: Much as comparative marker
Description: The unemployment position is much severe than in Singapore.

Name: As/to as comparative markers
Description: worse as ‘worse than’

Name: Comparatives and superlatives of participles
Description: fightingest, singingest

Name: Comparative marking only with than
Description: He loves his car than [‘more than’] his children;

Name: Comparative marking with more…and
Description: They would have more powder on their hands and in their faces ‘…than in their faces’

Name: Zero marking of degree
Description: He is one of the radical students that you can ever find.

Name: Attributive adjectival modifiers follow head noun
Description: bikpela sospen ain ‘a big iron saucepan’

Name: Wider range of uses of progressive be + V-ing than in StE: extension to stative verbs
Description: Iʼm liking this; What are you wanting?

Name: Wider range of uses of progressive be + V-ing than in StE: extension to habitual contexts
Description: My holiday (Saturday, Sunday), I am usually going to library, China town, city, etc.

Name: Invariant be as habitual marker
Description: He be sick ‘He is always/usually sick’

Name: Do as habitual marker
Description: He does catch fish pretty.

Name: Other non-standard habitual markers: synthetic
Description: I drinks three and four cups to a meal.

Name: Other non-standard habitual markers: analytic
Description: He do be sick a lot; Me stap ronron ‘I jog [every day]’

Name: Progressive marker stap or stay
Description: Ol i wokabout i stap ‘they are walking’; Hem i stap kaekae ‘He is eating’

Name: Be sat/stood with progressive meaning
Description: When youʼre stood [‘are standing’] there you can see the flames.

Name: There with past participle in resultative contexts
Description: There’s something fallen down the sink .

Name: Medial object perfect
Description: And you eat nothing till you have the stations made.

Name: After-perfect
Description: Sheʼs after selling the boat ‘She has just sold the boat’

Name: Levelling of the difference between present perfect and simple past: simple past for StE present perfect
Description: Were you ever in London?

Name: Levelling of the difference between present perfect and simple past: present perfect for StE simple past
Description: Some of us have been to New York years ago.

Name: Simple present for continuative or experiential perfect
Description: I’m in here about four months; I know her since she was a child; I’m here for twenty years

Name: Be as perfect auxiliary
Description: Theyʼre not left school yet.

Name: Do as unstressed tense marker
Description: This man what do own this; That girl what did smile at me

Name: Completive/perfect done
Description: He done go fishing; You don ate what I has sent you?

Name: Completive/perfect have/be + done + past participle
Description: He is done gone .

Name: “Sequential” or “irrealis” be done
Description: If you love your enemies, they be done eat you alive in this society .

Name: Completive/perfect marker slam
Description: I slam told you not to mess up.

Name: Ever as marker of experiential perfect
Description: I ever see the movie ‘I have seen the movie’

Name: Perfect marker already
Description: We did move here a week already ‘We had moved here a week previously’; Were you there already? ‘Have you been there before?’

Name: Finish-derived completive markers
Description: Wakum gaden blong mifala finis ‘I have completed my work in our garden’

Name: Past tense/anterior marker been
Description: I been cut the bread.

Name: Anterior had + bare root
Description: Hii had iit do bred biifoh hii goo tuu skuul ‘he ate the bread before he went to school’,

Name: Loosening of sequence of tenses rule
Description: I noticed the van I came in ‘I noticed the van I had come in’

Name: Go-based future markers
Description: e.g. Uh ain ga go nowhere ‘I won’t go anywhere’; He gon build my house

Name: Volition-based future markers other than will
Description: A tel dem pipl da nobadi els wan de da kampʼI told them that nobody else will be at the campʼ; Em i laik go long gaden ʼhe likes/is about to go to the gardenʼ

Name: Come-based future/ingressive markers
Description: I am coming to cook your meal  ‘I am about to cook your meal’

Name: Present tense forms for neutral future reference
Description: I think I make one new dress for Chinese New Year.

Name: Is for am/will with 1st person singular
Description: I’s going to town ‘I am/will be going to town’ ; I’s not ‘I won’t’

Name: Would for (distant) future in contrast to will (immediate future)
Description: I would eat/would be eating rice tomorrow

Name: Would in if-clauses
Description: If Iʼd be you…

Name: Double modals
Description: I tell you what we might should do.

Name: Epistemic mustn’t
Description: This mustnʼt [‘canʼt’] be true.

Name: Present tense forms of modals used where StE has past tense forms
Description: I wish that people in the world will [‘would’] get educated;[...] they can [‘might’] be wild, but theyʼre human beings

Name: Want/need + past participle
Description: The cat wants petted; The car needs washed

Name: New quasi-modals: core modal meanings
Description: We liketa drowned that day ‘we almost drowned that day’; He belongs to come here today ‘he ought to come here today’

Name: New quasi-modals: aspectual meanings
Description: Theyʼre fixinʼ to leave town ‘theyʼre about to leave’; Iʼm finna go‘Iʼm about to go’; It useta didnʼt matter whether you walked in late or not ‘[Formerly] it didnʼt matter...’

Name: Non-standard use of modals for politeness reasons
Description: This furniture may be [‘is to be’] removed tomorrow; Must I make you some tea? ‘Shall I…’

Name: Levelling of past tense/past participle verb forms: regularization of irregular verb paradigms
Description: catch-catched-catched

Name: Levelling of past tense/past participle verb forms: unmarked forms
Description: frequent with give and run

Name: Levelling of past tense/past participle verb forms: past tense replacing the past participle
Description: He had went

Name: Levelling of past tense/past participle verb forms: past participle replacing the past tense form
Description: He gone to Mary.

Name: Zero past tense forms of regular verbs
Description: I walk  ‘I walked’ [but not That door bin close ‘The door closed’]

Name: Double marking of past tense
Description: camed; didnʼt stayed

Name: A-prefixing on ing-forms
Description: They wasnʼt a-doinʼ nothinʼ wrong.

Name: A-prefixing on elements other than ing-forms
Description: a-back; acome

Name: Special inflected forms of be
Description: bees for present subjunctive

Name: Special inflected forms of do
Description: I junt ‘I don’t’

Name: Special inflected forms of have
Description: he amn’t ‘he hasn’t’

Name: Distinctive forms for auxiliary vs. full verb meanings of primary verbs
Description: She done it, didnʼt she?; We has a muck round here [full verb] vs. We havenʼt been there since we got married[auxiliary]

Name: Other forms/phrases for copula ʼbeʼ: before NPs
Description: Ebry day da fishing day… ‘Every day is a day for fishing…’

Name: Other forms/phrases for copula ʼbeʼ: before locatives
Description: Den pikin ben de na skoro ‘The children were at school’

Name: Other forms/phrases for copula ʼbeʼ: before AdjPs
Description: Shi stei sik ‘She is sick’

Name: Transitive verb suffix -em/-im/-um
Description: Mi bin bai-im kaikai ‘I bought-TR some food’

Name: Use of gotten and got with distinct meanings (dynamic vs. static)
Description: Theyʼve gotten a new car [‘have received’] vs. Theyʼve got a new car [‘possess’]; Theyʼve gotten interested [‘developed an interest’] vs. Theyʼve got interested [‘are interested’]

Name: Use of gotten instead of got
Description: Finbank has gotten a new career website[‘possess’]

Name: Use of verbal suffix -ing with forms other than present participle/gerund
Description: I can driving now; Thou wants thy tow [‘hair’] cutting

Name: Was for conditional were
Description: If I was you

Name: Serial verbs: give = ʼto, forʼ
Description: Karibuk giv mi [lit.: carry-book give me] ‘Give the book to me’

Name: Serial verbs: go = ʼmovement away fromʼ
Description: Yu a tek di bos go Kingstan? [lit.: you PROG take the bus go Kingston] ‘Are you taking the bus to Kingston?’

Name: Serial verbs: come = ʼmovement towardsʼ
Description: Den bring den kam [lit.: them bring them come] ‘They brought them back’

Name: Serial verbs: constructions with 3 verbs
Description: Im wan mi fi go kya im kom [lit.: him want me for go carry him come] ‘He wants me to bring him’

Name: Serial verbs: constructions with 4 or more verbs
Description: Agnes ron komot go lef in mama na makit [lit.: Agnes run come-out go leave POSS mama LOC market] ʼAgnes rushed out to drop her mother off at the marketʼ

Name: Give passive: NP1 (patient) + give + NP2 (agent) + V
Description: John give his boss scold ‘John was scolded by his boss’ (implying that John gave his boss reason to scold him)

Name: Multiple negation / negative concord
Description: He wonʼt do no harm.

Name: Ain’t as the negated form of be
Description: Theyʼre all in there, ainʼt they?

Name: Ainʼt as the negated form of have
Description: I ainʼt had a look at them yet.

Name: Ainʼt as generic negator before a main verb
Description: Something I ainʼt know about

Name: Invariant don’t for all persons in the present tense
Description: He donʼt like me.

Name: Never as preverbal past tense negator
Description: He never came ‘He didnʼt come’

Name: No as preverbal negator
Description: Me no iit brekfus

Name: Not as a preverbal negator
Description: Nail not float

Name: No more/nomo as negative existential marker
Description: Nomo nating insai dea ‘There isnʼt anything in there’

Name: Was – weren’t split
Description: The boys was interested, but Mary werenʼt.

Name: Amnʼt in tag questions
Description: Iʼm here, amnʼt I?

Name: Invariant non-concord tags
Description: They had them in their hair, innit?

Name: Invariant tag can or not?
Description: I want to go home, can or not? ‘Can I go home?’; Answer the question, can or not? ‘Do you know the answer to the question?’

Name: Fronted invariant tag
Description: Isn’t, I can colour this red? ‘I can colour this red, can’t I?’

Name: Special negative verbs in imperatives
Description: Du miek agli ‘donʼt pull a face’

Name: Non-standard system underlying responses to negative yes/no questions
Description: Isnʼt he arriving tomorrow? - Yes [= ‘No, he isnʼt’]/No [= ‘Yes, he is’]

Name: Invariant present tense forms due to zero marking for the third person singular
Description: So she show up and say “Whatʼs up?”

Name: Invariant present tense forms due to generalization of 3rd person –s to all persons
Description: I sees the house.

Name: Existential / presentational there’s/there is/there was with plural subjects
Description: Thereʼs two men waiting in the hall.

Name: Variant forms of dummy subject there in existential clauses
Description: They is something bad wrong with her; Itʼs a new person here ‘Thereʼs a new person here’; Ø ga li aystaz we grow pan dem [lit.: got little oysters REL grow on them] ‘There are small oysters growing (on the mangrove trees)’

Name: Deletion of auxiliary be: before progressive
Description: So you Ø always thinking about where where you go to work.

Name: Deletion of auxiliary be: before gonna
Description: I Ø gonna go work.

Name: Deletion of copula be: before NPs
Description: He Ø a good teacher.

Name: Deletion of copula be: before AdjPs
Description: She Ø smart.

Name: Deletion of copula be: before locatives
Description: She Ø at home.

Name: Deletion of auxiliary have
Description: I Ø eaten my lunch.

Name: Was/were generalization
Description: You were hungry but he were thirsty; or: You was hungry but he was thirsty

Name: Agreement sensitive to subject type
Description: birds sings vs. they sing

Name: Agreement sensitive to position of subject
Description: I sing and dances

Name: Northern Subject Rule
Description: I sing [vs. *I sings]; birds sings; I sing and dances

Name: Invariant be with non-habitual function
Description: Here I be (presentational); I be cold (copula)

Name: Relativizer that or what  in non-restrictive contexts
Description: My daughter, that/what lives in London,…

Name: Which for ‘who’
Description: my brother, which...

Name: Relativizer as
Description: He was a chap as got a living anyhow

Name: Relativizer at
Description: This is the man at painted my house

Name: Relativizer where or a form derived from where
Description: My father was one of the founders oʼ de Underground Railroad where help de slaves to run way to de North

Name: Relativizer what or a form derived from what
Description: This is the man what painted my house; Di man wo tif di granat don go ‘The man who stole the peanuts has gone’

Name: Relativizer doubling
Description: But these, these little fellahs that which had stayed befoʼ God prayinʼ…

Name: Use of analytic or cliticized that his/that’s, what his/what’s, at’s, who his instead of whose
Description: the man whatʼs wife has died

Name: Gapping/zero-relativization in subject position
Description: The man Ø lives there is a nice chap.

Name: Resumptive/shadow pronouns
Description: This is the house which I painted it yesterday.

Name: Postposed one as sole relativizer
Description: That boy pinch my sister one very naughty ‘That boy who pinched my sister is very naughty’

Name: Correlative constructions
Description: Which-one I put in the jar, that-one is good ‘The ones [pickles] I put in the jar are best’

Name: “Linking relative clauses”
Description: …unless you are going to get 88 which some universities are not going to give those marks

Name: Deletion of stranded prepositions in relative clauses (“preposition chopping”)
Description: …like a big yard that you do gardening anʼall [in deleted]

Name: Reduced relative phrases preceding head-noun
Description: That Neelaʼs-knitted jersey is gone white ‘That jersey which Neela knitted/knitted by Neela has gone white’

Name: Say-based complementizers
Description: We hear say you gone to da city ‘We heard that you [were] gone to the city’

Name: For-based complementizers
Description: I hard fi kraas di riba ‘It’s hard to cross the river’

Name: Unsplit for to in infinitival purpose clauses
Description: We always had gutters in the winter time for to drain the water away.

Name: For (to) as infinitive marker
Description: You werenae allowed at this time for to go and take another job on.

Name: As what / than what in comparative clauses
Description: Itʼs harder than what you think it is.

Name: Existentials with forms of get
Description: E got some sand there ‘There is some sand’; Ova hyee get tumoch bush ‘Thereʼs too much bush over here’

Name: Existentials with forms of have
Description: Ma yu abi son mma tu di man dede kaba [lit.: But you have some woman REL the man die PRF] ‘But there are some women whose husbands have already died’

Name: Substitution of that-clause for infinitival subclause
Description: I wanted that I should get leave .

Name: Deletion of to before infinitives
Description: Allow him Ø go.

Name: Addition of to where StE has bare infinitive
Description: He made me to do it.

Name: Non-finite clause complements with bare root form rather than -ing form
Description: Him start tell di cousins all sort a someting ‘He started telling the cousins all kinds of things’

Name: Clause-final but = ʼthoughʼ
Description: Well I warnt so very cold but.

Name: Clause-final but = ʼreallyʼ
Description: I fright for dogs, but eh! ‘Iʼm really afraid of dogs’

Name: No subordination; chaining construction linking two main verbs (motion and activity)
Description: I bin go dere work; Stay longer, they have to over-charge ‘If you stay longer, they have to charge more’

Name: Conjunction doubling: clause + conj. + conj. + clause
Description: He has been in this school for five years, still yet he is not tired

Name: Conjunction doubling: correlative conj.s
Description: Although you are smart, but you are not appreciated; So when I was a baby, so my father-an’-them shifted to Sezela

Name: Omission of StE prepositions
Description: He came out Ø hospital; She went Ø town;  We’re going there Ø Tuesday

Name: Use of postpositions
Description: e.g. the chalkboard under; night time ‘at night’, Telugu way ‘in Telugu’, morning  part ‘in the morning’

Name: Affirmative anymore ‘nowadays’
Description: That’s the trouble with airplanes any more; Anymore they have a hard time protecting things like that

Name: Adverb-forming suffixes –way and –time
Description: long-way, quick-way; dark-time, late-time

Name: Degree modifier adverbs have the same form as adjectives
Description: Thatʼs real good

Name: Other adverbs have the same form as adjectives
Description: Come quick!

Name: Too; too much; very much ‘very’ as qualifier
Description: It is too difficult ‘…very difficult’;  i sofa tuu motch ‘(s)he was suffering very much’

Name: Other options for clefting than StE
Description: It’s looking for more land a lot of them are; They ride bikes is what I see them do

Name: Other possibilities for fronting than StE
Description: To my sister sometime I speak English.

Name: Sentence-initial focus marker
Description: A wan piki pikin boi e moksi smenti drape ‘It’s a little boy that mixes cement there’; Na mí was di kalbas ‘Me, I’m the one that washed the calabash’

Name: “Negative inversion”
Description: Didnʼt nobody show up ‘Nobody showed up’; Thereʼs an old house up here, but donʼt nobody live in it ‘…nobody lives in it’

Name: Inverted word order in indirect questions
Description: Iʼm wondering what are you gonna do.

Name: No inversion/no auxiliaries in wh-questions
Description: What you doing? What he wants?

Name: No inversion/no auxiliaries in main clause yes/no questions
Description: You get the point? You liked India?

Name: Doubly filled COMP-position with wh-words
Description: What who has eaten? ‘Who ate what?’

Name: Superlative marker most occurring before head noun
Description: The most thing I like is apples ‘The thing I like most is apples’

Name: Either order of objects in double object constructions (if both objects are pronominal)
Description: He couldn’t give him it; I tan [‘took’] it her back

Name: Presence of subject in imperatives
Description: Go you there!

Name: Like as a focussing device
Description: How did you get away with that like? Like for one found five quid, that was like three quid, like two-fifty each.

Name: Like as a quotative particle
Description: And she was like “What do you mean?”
